title: JavaScript Basics
description: Test your knowledge of JavaScript fundamentals.

questions.text: What is the output of the following code?
questions.explanation: NaN stands for Not-a-Number, but its type is actually 'number'.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a primitive type in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Object is a reference type, not a primitive type. Primitives include String, Number, Boolean, Null, Undefined, Symbol, and BigInt.

questions.text: What is the result of `2 + '2'` in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: When the + operator is used with a string, it performs concatenation. The number 2 is converted to a string.

questions.text: What does the following code output?
questions.explanation: Due to floating-point precision issues in binary arithmetic, 0.1 + 0.2 results in 0.30000000000000004, which is not strictly equal to 0.3.

questions.text: Which method is used to remove the last element from an array?
questions.explanation: `pop()` removes the last element. `shift()` removes the first. `push()` adds to the end. `unshift()` adds to the beginning.

questions.text: What is the output of this code?
questions.explanation: Arrays are reference types. `b` references the same array in memory as `a`. Modifying `b` also modifies `a`.

questions.text: How do you check if a property exists in an object?
questions.explanation: The `in` operator returns true if the specified property is in the specified object or its prototype chain.

options.text: To filter elements based on a condition
To execute a function for each element
To create a new array with the results of calling a function on every element
To reduce the array to a single value

questions.explanation: `map()` creates a new array populated with the results of calling a provided function on every element in the calling array.

questions.text: What will be logged to the console?
questions.explanation: Due to hoisting, the declaration `var x` is moved to the top of the function scope, but the initialization `x = 5` remains where it is. So `x` is undefined when logged.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct way to create a Promise?
questions.explanation: The Promise constructor takes a function (executor) which receives `resolve` and `reject` arguments.
